newsitem.title: UK: Southern Electric firms on bid speculation.
newsitem.headline: Southern Electric firms on bid speculation.

text.p: Shares in Southern Electric Plc firmed in pre-market trading on Friday, after newspaper reports raised speculation of a bid from power generator PowerGen Plc.
Southern shares were quoted up 5p at 416 by 0713 GMT, though no volume was recorded in the stock, while PowerGen was up 2-1/2p at 696-1/2 in volume of 155,000 shares.

PowerGen, which last year was blocked by the government from bidding for Southern's fellow regional electricity company (REC) Midlands Electricity on anti-competitive grounds, is still smarting from the surprise ruling which sent its shares plunging.

The group's chief executive and chairman Ed Wallis was quoted as saying that while the company would still consider buying a REC, it was too early to say whether the new Labour Government had the same view as the former Conservative government that vetoed its bid.
The Financial Times said Wallis indicated no urgency, although he did say the company was looking for a big acquisition.
PowerGen, which reported near top-of-the-range annual results on Thursday, has a robust balance sheet with negligible debt.
It's shares, which have risen around a third since last October, rose 4.0p to 698p in the first few minutes of trade, near it's year high of 701.
Southern Electric declined to comment on any bid hints, noting that it did not wish to add to market speculation.
Southern is the last remaining independent REC after its 11 peers were snapped up in a bidding frenzy that began in earnest in 1995 and lasted over one year.
